question_sentence: Juneteenth commemorates June 19, 1865, the day Union Maj. Gen. Gordon Granger (pictured here) informed slaves of their emancipation from slavery. In which state did this event take place?
evidence: Granger delivered the news, known as General Orders, No. 3, in Galveston, Texas.

question_sentence: Granger’s announcement came almost three years after the Emancipation Proclamation, the famous executive order abolishing slavery issued by which US President?
evidence: President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863, as the nation approached its third year of bloody civil war. The proclamation declared “that all persons held as slaves” within the rebellious states “are, and henceforward shall be free.”

question_sentence: Which Constitutional Amendment officially abolished slavery across the United States?
evidence: The 13th Amendment, ratified on December 6, 1865, officially abolished chattel slavery in the United States.

question_sentence: What two Union border states continued to practice slavery up until the 13th Amendment was ratified?
evidence: Slavery remained technically legal in Union states until 1865, and some areas of Delaware and Kentucky continued the practice until that time.

question_sentence: How many slaves were estimated to be in the United States in the early 1860s before slavery was outlawed?
evidence: It’s estimated that there were more than 3.9 million slaves in the United States as of 1860 — while only 500,000 Black individuals lived as free persons during that time.

question_sentence: Which state was the first to recognize Juneteenth as a state holiday?
evidence: Texas was the first state to recognize Juneteenth as a state holiday on January 1, 1980.

question_sentence: Which US President signed a bill making Juneteenth a federal holiday?
evidence: On June 17, 2021, President Joe Biden signed a bill into law recognizing Juneteenth National Independence Day. Biden said the moment will go down as “one of the greatest honors” of his presidency.

question_sentence: A revised red, white and blue flag honoring Juneteenth was introduced in 2000. What symbol is at the center of the flag?
evidence: The flag, created by activist Ben Haith, founder of the National Juneteenth Celebration Foundation, has a white star in the middle representing the Lone Star State of Texas as well as the freedom of African Americans in all 50 states.

question_sentence: What is another name often used to refer to Juneteenth?
evidence: Juneteenth is also referred to as Freedom Day, along with Emancipation Day and Jubilee Day.

question_sentence: What beverage was once popular and synonymous with Juneteenth celebrations?
evidence: Arriving on the heels of spring, Juneteenth festivities typically involve picnics, with red foods and drinks like strawberry soda dominating those spreads. The color red is believed to represent the blood shed by enslaved African ancestors.

question_sentence: True or false: With this week’s win in the NBA Finals, the Denver Nuggets claimed their first NBA championship.
Author Cormac McCarthy died this week at age 89. He won the Pulitzer Prize for which novel?
Thousands of online communities went dark this week to protest API changes on which social media platform?
Pat Sajak announced this week that after next season, he will step down as host of which game show?
A member of which band said he used artificial intelligence to create his iconic group's "last record"?
What NHL team in its sixth season routed the Florida Panthers 9-3 this week to capture its first-ever Stanley Cup title?
Novak Djokovic defeated Casper Ruud in the French Open to claim his 23rd Grand Slam title. Who is he now tied with for major singles titles?
Travelers through what city experienced major travel delays after a tanker truck fire caused an elevated portion of I-95 to collapse?
Which NFL player says he lost more than 100 pounds on a water fast, which experts warn can be dangerous?
Users who clicked search results between Oct. 2006 and Sept. 2013 may be entitled to a cut of a $23 million settlement from which search engine?
What is the title of the new Banksy exhibition opening at Glasgow’s Gallery of Modern Art this weekend?
evidence: Banky’s first official solo exhibition in 14 years will feature stencils used to create many of the graffiti artist’s most iconic works from across his career.

question_sentence: China has reportedly reached a secret deal to build a spy base in which country?
evidence: China has agreed a multibillion-dollar deal to build an electronic eavesdropping facility on the island that could allow Beijing to eavesdrop on US communications, according to The Wall Street Journal. The US and Cuban governments cast strong doubt on the report.

question_sentence: Novak Djokovic’s victory in the French Open final on Sunday takes his total tally of grand slam wins to how many?
evidence: The Serbian tennis champion defeated Casper Ruud 7-6 (1), 6-3, 7-5 to surpass Rafael Nadal’s grand slams record.

question_sentence: The Commons privileges committee would have suspended Boris Johnson from Parliament for how long over Partygate if he were still an MP?
evidence: In a report published on Thursday, the privileges committee said that had Johnson not already resigned, he should have faced a three-month suspension for deliberately misleading MPs over Partygate.

question_sentence: Revellers pelted each other with more than 10,000kg of what food at a festival in the Colombian town of Sutamarchán?
evidence: The Gran Tomatina festival celebrates the end of the harvest season. The annual food fight was cancelled during the pandemic but returned for a 15th staging on Sunday.

question_sentence: Who won the 2023 Tony Award for best leading actress?
evidence: The Liverpool-born star scooped the Tony Award for her Broadway debut in the one-woman play “Prima Facie”. Comer also won an Olivier Award earlier this year for the West End version of the production.

question_sentence: Poland’s bus route 666 will now be known as what?
evidence: The operator of the bus route, which terminates at the Polish seaside resort of Hel, is making the name change following pressure from religious groups. For more odd and unexpected news, sign up to the Tall Tales newsletter.

question_sentence: Which US author is pulling a novel set in Russia from publication?
evidence: The best-selling author of “Eat, Pray, Love” asked her publishers to postpone the publication of her novel “The Snow Forest”, which is set in 20th century Siberia, following a backlash from Ukrainian readers. Find out more with The Week Unwrapped podcast.

question_sentence: Activists from Just Stop Oil halted an opera performance at Glyndebourne by doing what?
evidence: Three Just Stop Oil protesters interrupted a performance on Thursday of Francis Poulenc’s “Dialogues des Carmélites” at the opera festival, in East Sussex. The performance restarted after a 20-minute delay following the removal of the activists, who were not arrested.
choices: Setting off a confetti bomb and blasting air horns
Loudly singing songs from “Phantom of the Opera”
Doing cartwheels across the stage while naked

question_sentence: What percentage of people in the UK have a strong interest in the news, according to a new study?
evidence: A global study by researchers at Oxford University’s Reuters Institute found that worldwide, 48% of people were very or extremely interested in the news – down from 63% in 2017. The proportion was even lower in the UK, as audiences “cut back on depressing news” to protect their mental health, said the study authors.
